definition[0]: attempts to make people think something is good or important by talking about it a lot on television, the radio etc – used to show disapproval
example[0]: Some experts are concerned that the new drug won’t live up to all the hype.
example[1]: Despite the media hype, I found the film very disappointing.
definition[1]: to try to make people think something is good or important by talking about it a lot on television, the radio etc
example[2]: The director is just using the controversy to hype his movie.
definition[2]: when advertisers try to make the public interested in someone or something through advertisements that make people talk about them a lot on television and radio
example[3]: Their status has been gained through their pursuit of quality, not through public relations hype.
example[4]: the hype surrounding any new film
definition[3]: to try to make the public interested in someone or something through advertisements or by getting them talked about a lot on television and radio
example[5]: The unit trust industry is usually quick to hype its products.
example[6]: Competitors criticized the group for hyping up products it can’t deliver.
definition[4]: to deceive people by changing figures or results, usually to make a situation look better than it really is
example[7]: The company admitted that it had hyped customer orders and faked records to match those orders.
